Award.AwardTitle: Phase II Grant Industry University Cooperative Research Center (IUCRC) for GRid-connected Advanced Power Electronic Systems (GRAPES), University of Arkansas
Award.AbstractNarration:
The GRid-connected Advanced Power Electronic Systems (GRAPES) center (https://grapes.uark.edu) is focused on research and development of the tools, technologies, and designs of the 21st century modernized electric power grid. This center is led by the University of Arkansas (UA) with two domestic partner institutions: the University of South Carolina and the University of Wisconsin Milwaukee. The GRAPES center will focus on issues involving renewable integration, microgrid hardware and controls, and fast-acting power conditioning and protection devices that form the basis of the 21st century electric power grid. This work will impact millions in the U.S. through enhanced grid reliability and efficiency, thus lower greenhouse gas emissions. The Center will make full use of an established national-caliber facility for test and evaluation of distribution-level power electronic equipment. This will enable validation of research findings and accelerated insertion of new solid-state equipment into the power grid. GRAPES will train students to develop and manage the next generation of power systems, thereby helping to mitigate the shortage of power engineers. GRAPES will continue to establish new courses that will integrate research with education to produce students not just competitive, but superlative in their ownership of unique skills and knowledge.

Power electronics enables the integration of renewable energy sources such as solar and wind, energy storage, new grid architectures more resilient to natural and man-made attack, and greater efficiency, all of which reduce greenhouse gas emissions while improving energy security for the nation. A team of highly qualified academic researchers, guided by an industry advisory board, with extensive experience in power systems and power electronics, electronic packaging, semiconductor device modeling, and controls will focus on the design, development, and evaluation of grid-connected power electronic equipment. Examples of such equipment include advanced solid-state transformers, microgrid control methods, novel protection equipment for both ac and dc power distribution, new converter architectures that promote higher efficiencies when interfacing renewable resources to the grid, and fundamental technologies such as new electronic packaging for high voltage applications and semiconductor device models for advanced analysis of power electronic systems. In every case, projects are selected and guided by the industry members of the center to ensure maximum relevance and impact to the industry in either component development, equipment development, or new operational methods for the electric power industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Phase II GRAPES funded and implemented 49 projects among the Center sites. The most important Phase II activities for the GRAPES Center focused on industry driven research activities addressing the priorities identified by the Industry Advisory Board (IAB). Phase II GRAPES has produced phase balancing technology, mobile power substation designs, multi-port solid-state power transformers, multilevel power converters with novel fault diagnosis and resiliency, 10 kV active gate driver technology and many others. The deepest impacts of these GRAPES projects and technologies have been in three areas: a) hardware design techniques, control methods, and software models and tools that member companies currently use, b) investigations into the bounds of what power electronics and wide bandgap technologies can achieve in grid applications through studies, prototypes and demonstrations, and c) better prepared electrical engineering graduates, at all degree levels, for industry. 

Because the I/UCRC program is designed to develop precompetitive research, it is important for the investigators and the company partners to collaborate and seek additional funding for valuable research started in the GRAPES Center. This constituted a major activity in the Center during Phase II. It is important to provide examples of sponsors who supported precompetitive projects that were initially funded by GRAPES. Some examples of efforts to elevate GRAPES technology by acquiring additional funding include proposals funded by ARPA-e, Army Research Laboratory, NSF GOALI, DOE Sunshot and several NSF CAREER awards to new professors who joined the UA Power Group and the GRAPES team.

During Phase II, there have been 10 semi annual meetings where these projects and others were presented to the IAB. The semiannual meetings give investigators a chance to update ongoing active projects, propose new projects and provide final reports for projects that have been completed. Plus there have been two strategic planning meetings. During these meetings the IAB and the investigators discuss research priorities and  determine whether or not these priorities of the center are in line with industry interests at that time. 

One way to expand the impact of the intellectual merit is to expand the partnership of institutions involved in GRAPES. During Phase II GRAPES saw the addition of a new site, University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee. Including this site increased the number of faculty to the GRAPES Center, diversified the abilities of GRAPES and expanded the industrial membership. 

The addition of an international component to the Center has also made a big difference. RWTH Aachen is arguably the largest and most accomplished power and energy group in Germany with substantial industry support. During Phase II, the Center also added two universities in South Korea - Yonsei University and Korea University. These two schools have jointly formed a Korean site for GRAPES. This expansion continues the formal establishment of the GRAPES Global Institute (GGI).

Broader Impacts

Phase II GRAPES also had greater impacts on students, industry and society. During this Phase II period, GRAPES supported many students and 21 of them graduated and many moved on to get industry employment. GRAPES is a good training platform for students because it provides them the opportunity to engage real projects that impact industry partners. Students are able to interact with industry, present ideas and results to industry and receive internships from industry partners. Students who have been hired by industry members have been at all degree levels and were better prepared than they otherwise would have been without the GRAPES experience.

Industry benefits from technology transferred for their use. Well over a dozen types of technology has been developed and provided to industry for their use during Phase II GRAPES. 

As the center further matured during Phase II, technologies developed by GRAPES researchers will ncrease the use of power electronics in grid-connected equipment. This will improve the efficiency and reliability of this equipment, saving consumers and utilities time and money. Some of the technologies being developed by our researchers will also help lead to increased penetration of renewable resources such as solar and wind energy into our national grid.

During the entirety of Phase II technologies developed by GRAPES researchers increased the use of power electronics in grid-connected equipment. They improved the efficiency and reliability of equipment, saving consumers and utilities time and money. Some of the technologies developed by our researchers also helped lead to increased penetration of renewable resources such as solar and wind energy into our national grid.

As we close Phase II, we have realized that our impact has become stronger. Through our research we are impacting not only the electric power grid, but also transportation, cybersecurity, and other power electronic applications. These other disciplines are impacted through other centers, federal grants, and industry-based contracts. Most importantly, these technologies and well trained students benefit both industry and society.
